title: Glossy Pop Newsletter: Smashbox aims to reclaim relevance by refocusing on its OG products
summary: In 2000, Smashbox launched The Original Photo Finish Smooth & Blur Oil-Free Primer, which, in the 25 years since, has been repackaged several times, but never reformulated. "It is an icon," said Michelle Shigemasa, Smashbox's global gm. Since 2000, Smashbox has sold 20 million units of the SKU, and today, one Photo Finish Smooth & Blur Primer is sold every minute in North America.

title: Glossy Podcast: Valentino’s new CEO, Guess’s acquisition and TJ Maxx’s earnings — plus, a chat with Off Season’s Vicky Picca
summary: This week, we take a look at Ricardo Bellini’s appointment as the new CEO of Valentino, the acquisition of Guess by Authentic Brands Group and the good earnings results from TJ Maxx. Later in the episode, we have a dispatch from our Sports Opportunity digital event, in which our editor-in-chief, Jill Manoff, spoke with Vicky Picca, the president of the sports fashion brand Off Season.

title: Inside Estée Lauder’s $14 billion reset: AI, brand trouble and a travel retail retreat

title: Fashion Briefing: How Mack Weldon turned a line of cotton sweats into its biggest customer acquisition tool

title: The secret to a successful pop-up event with 3 industry leaders, plus news

title: TJX to open 1,800 new stores as off-price thrives amid tariff pressures

title: Exclusive: Can bridal take off in resale?

title: Brands sound off on when to run a Black Friday sale and how to stand out, at Modern Retail’s Holiday Strategies Town Hall
summary: On Tuesday afternoon, Glossy and Modern Retail reporters and editors gathered with Glossy+ and Modern Retail+  subscribers to discuss what’s top of mind for people in the industry as they are preparing for the holidays. Here's a recap of the conversation.

summary: The editor in chief of Esquire represents something of a paradox: a digital native who came up through the ranks of online journalism.

title: Beauty & Wellness Briefing: Is this the end of foam sunscreen? —plus, industry news
summary: This week, I checked in with formulation and packaging experts to break down the FDA letters sent to sunscreen brands like Vacation and Supergoop warning that their whipped and foam sunscreens are not in compliance with federal law. The brands have 15 days to respond, which is likely to include a recall of products from Sephora, Ulta Beauty, Target, CVS, Revolve and Nordstrom shelves. Additionally, Sephora bets on another artist-founded color cosmetics line, P&G Beauty gets a new CEO, and OneSkin takes on $20 million in funding as biotech-powered beauty heats up.

summary: We’re excited to have Lively speak about the evolution of Blake Brown at Glossy Pop NYC on September 5.

title: From tennis to baseball to the NFL, jewelry brands are embracing sports for viral growth
summary: While the rest of fashion has been crossing over with sports for years, jewelry is newer to the arena. The contrast between the intensity and performance of sports and the luxuriousness of fine jewelry makes for an odd pairing. But as the line between sports and the rest of culture increasingly blurs, jewelry brands are finding the massive audience of sports and NIL athletes too tempting to ignore.

title: Where did Target and Ulta Beauty’s shop-in-shop partnership go wrong?
summary: On Thursday, Target and Ulta Beauty announced an end date to the shop-in-shop partnership that kicked off in 2021. Glossy spoke to experts about the potential, execution and tumble of the brick-and-mortar experiment and what it means for beauty retail.

title: Glossy Pop Newsletter: Glow Recipe leans into ‘leak’ marketing for its new launch
summary: Early last year, Glow Recipe's as-yet-unreleased bronzing drops went viral when creator Aysha Harun posted them with the clickbait-y hook, "Did I accidentally get sent an unreleased Glow Recipe product?!?" Since then, leaks in beauty have become somewhat of a thing.

title: Coach CEO Todd Kahn on navigating tariffs and the sudden end of de minimis
summary: Coach CEO Todd Kahn explains how the brand will address a $160 million tariff impact from the sudden August 2025 end of the United States de minimis rule while sustaining growth after a record fourth quarter.

summary: While selling out makes good headlines, it also means leaving sales on the table. But since bringing its Bronzing Drops back in stock in July, Westman Atelier is making use of the summer to put renewed focus on the launch.
